Sentences: Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: I will start with a recap of our discussions, including our assessment of the outlook for the economy and the judgments we made about our interest rate policy and our balance sheet.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: I will cover the decisions we made today as well as our ongoing discussions of matters on which we expect to make decisions in coming meetings.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: My colleagues and I have one overarching goal:  to sustain the economic expansion, with a strong job market and stable prices, for the benefit of the American people.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: The U.S. economy is in a good place, and we will continue to use our monetary policy tools to help keep it there.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: The jobs picture continues to be strong, with the unemployment rate near historic lows and with stronger wage gains.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Inflation remains near our 2 percent goal.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: We continue to expect that the American economy will grow at a solid pace in 2019, although likely slower than the very strong pace of 2018.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: We believe that our current policy stance is appropriate at this time.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Despite this positive outlook, over the past few months we have seen some crosscurrents and conflicting signals about the outlook.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Growth has slowed in some major foreign economies, particularly in China and Europe.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: There is elevated uncertainty around several unresolved government policy issues, including Brexit, ongoing trade negotiations, and the effects from the partial government shutdown in the United States.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Financial conditions tightened considerably late in 2018 and remain less supportive of growth than they were earlier in 2018.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: And, while most of the incoming domestic economic data have been solid, some surveys of business and conditions and the outlook evolve, we take that new information into account in setting our policies.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: We are now facing a somewhat contradictory picture of generally strong U.S. macroeconomic performance alongside growing evidence of crosscurrents.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: At such times, common-sense risk management suggests patiently awaiting greater clarity—an approach that has served policymakers well in the past.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: With that in mind, I’d like to spell out how the Federal Open Market Committee has been thinking about these issues.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: At our December meeting, we noted the solid outlook for steady growth, vigorous job creation, and price stability.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: We also stressed that the extent and timing of any rate increases were uncertain and would depend on incoming data and the evolving outlook.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: We therefore said that we would be paying close attention to global economic and financial developments and assessing their implications for the economic outlook.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Today the FOMC decided that the cumulative effects of those developments over the last several months warrant a patient, wait-and-see approach regarding future policy changes.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: In particular, our statement today says, “In light of global economic and financial developments and muted inflation pressures, the Committee will be patient as it determines what future adjustments to the target range for the federal funds rate may be appropriate.” This change was not driven by a major shift in the baseline outlook for the economy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Like many forecasters, we still see “sustained expansion of economic activity, strong labor market conditions, and inflation near .
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: . . 2 percent” as the likeliest case.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: But the crosscurrents I mentioned suggest the risk of a less favorable outlook.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: In addition, the case for raising rates has weakened somewhat.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: The traditional case for rate increases is to protect the economy from risks the recent drop in oil prices is likely to push headline inflation lower still in coming months.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Further, as we noted in our postmeeting statement, while survey-based measures of inflation expectations have been stable, financial market measures of inflation compensation have moved lower.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Similarly, the balance—the risk of financial imbalances appears to have receded, as a number of indicators that showed elevated levels of financial risk appetite last fall have moved closer to historical norms.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: In this environment, we believe we can best support the economy by being patient in evaluating the outlook before making any future adjustment to policy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Let me now turn to balance sheet normalization.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Over its past three meetings, the FOMC has held in-depth discussions on the final stages of this process.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Today we made some important progress in clarifying the path forward, as summarized in the Statement Regarding Monetary Policy Implementation and Balance Sheet Normalization that we released with today’s FOMC statement.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: The Committee made the fundamental decision today to continue indefinitely using our current operating procedure for implementing monetary policy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: That is, we will continue to use our administered rates to control the policy rate with an ample supply of reserves so that active management of reserves is not required.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: This is often called a “floor system” or an “abundant reserves system.”  Under the current set of operating procedures, as outlined in the implementation note released today, this means that the federal funds rate, our active policy tool, is held within its target range by appropriately setting the Federal Reserve’s administered rates of interest on reserves, as well as the offer rate on the overnight reverse repo facility, without managing the supply of reserves actively.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: As the minutes of our recent discussions have broader financial conditions.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Settling this central question clears the way for the FOMC to address a number of further questions regarding the remaining stages of balance sheet normalization.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: The decision to retain our current operating procedure means that, after allowing for currency in circulation, the ultimate size of our balance sheet will be driven principally by financial institutions’ demand for reserves, plus a buffer so that fluctuations in reserve demand do not require us to make frequent sizable market interventions.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Estimates of the level of reserve demand are quite uncertain, but we know that this demand in the post-crisis environment is far larger than before.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Higher reserve holdings are an important part of the stronger liquidity position that financial institutions must now hold.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Moreover, based on surveys and market intelligence, current estimates of reserve demand are considerably higher than estimates of a year or so ago.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: The implication is that the normalization of the size of the portfolio will be completed sooner, and with a larger balance sheet, than in previous estimates.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: In light of these estimates and the substantial progress we have made in reducing reserves, the Committee is now evaluating the appropriate timing for the end of balance sheet runoff.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: This decision will likely be part of a plan for gradually reaching our ultimate balance sheet goals while minimizing risks to achieving our dual-mandate objectives and avoiding unnecessary market disruption.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: We will be finalizing these plans at coming meetings.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: The process of balance sheet normalization is unprecedented.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Throughout this process we’ve attempted to lay out our plans well in advance, and we’ve been willing to make changes as we learn more about the process.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: The implementation and normalization statement released federal funds rate is our active monetary policy tool.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Second, as far as the particular details of normalization are concerned, we will not hesitate to make changes in light of economic and financial developments.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: This does not mean that we would use the balance sheet as an active tool, but occasional changes could be warranted.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Third, we repeat a sentence of the normalization principles we adopted in June of 2017.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: While the federal funds rate would remain our active tool of policy in a wide range of scenarios, we recognize that the economy could again present conditions in which federal funds rate policy is not sufficient.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: In those cases, the FOMC would be prepared to use its full range of tools, including balance sheet policy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Times of economic uncertainty put a premium on the clarity and predictability of FOMC policy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: We are committed to clearly explaining what we are doing and why we’re doing it, both regarding the path of rates and also regarding management of the balance sheet.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: We believe that this transparency is how we can best contribute to macroeconomic stability.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: I’ll be glad to take your questions.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Howard Schneider with Reuters.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: So you’ve said many times recently that policy was still accommodative and that it needn’t be so.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: You’ve said recently that policy—the state of the policy was still accommodative and that the economy didn’t require that anymore.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: If so, how do you justify the removal of the need for some further interest rate increases?
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: Basically, are we at neutral now, or does the economy still need accommodation?
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: We think that our policy is at the appropriate point right now.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: policy stance is appropriate.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentences: We had an extensive discussion of the baseline and also of the risks to the baseline, and the risks are, of course, the fact that financial conditions have tightened, that global growth has slowed, as well as some, let’s say, government-related risks like Brexit and trade discussions, and also the effects and ultimate disposition of the shutdown.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: So we looked at—we look at those, and the way we think of it is that policy—we will use our policy, and we have, to offset risks to the baseline.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: So we view the baseline as still solid, and part of that is the way we adjusted our baseline to address those risks.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s the way we’re thinking about that now.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Thanks.
Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Sentences: The Fed has linked its commitment to patience in part to subdued inflation outcomes.
Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Sentences: Thanks.
Speaker: SAM FLEMING.

Sentences: You know, generally speaking, we think the outlook is favorable, and we think that these crosscurrents that I referred to—these risks—are going to be with us for a while.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: We think there’s no pressing need to data.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: It will include all data relevant to our dual mandate of stable prices and maximum employment.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Remember that our inflation objective is a symmetric one, meaning that we are—we’re always trying to get to 2 percent, and we don’t look at—we look at inflation equally on both sides.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: So I can’t get into specific hypotheticals, but I do believe that we have a symmetric objective, and I believe we’ll act that way.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: We learned from the last minutes of the meeting that some of the tweaks you make to the statement have a lot more portent than we thought.
Speaker: RICHARD MILLER.

Speaker: RICHARD MILLER.

Speaker: RICHARD MILLER.

Speaker: RICHARD MILLER.

Sentences: Sorry—say again what the first question was?
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Speaker: RICHARD MILLER.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Your second end of these muted inflation pressures—are they both sort of things that are necessary for you to change this “patient” stance?
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: You know, it’s really hard to speak about generalities.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: We’ll be looking at everything, but I do think that, you know, muted inflation pressures—you know, you would want—I would want to see a need for further rate increases, and, for me, a big part of that would be inflation.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: It wouldn’t be the only thing, but it would certainly be important.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: So there are a lot of pieces to that, and we’ve learned over time that it’s—when making these—when designing these plans, like, for example, the original normalization plan, it’s good to take your time.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: But there are estimates, and I think they’re consistent with what I said, broadly speaking.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: So, just to clarify—I’m sorry, you did discuss reducing the pace of the runoff?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: That sounds like what you said, to me.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: There no decisions have been made.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: There are different pieces of the thing, and that is in the discussion as one of many pieces that is in the discussion.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: And that was reflected in the last minutes, actually.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Sentences: Thanks.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL.
